en: Vida y hechos del ingenioso cavallero Don Qvixote de la Mancha
Don Quixote knighted by the innkeeper
3.4 DQ knighted at inn by innkeeper

Don Quixote, knelt in the inn courtyard, is knighted by the innkeeper, who holds a book and raises a sword.Also in the scene, the two party girls (doña Molinera and doña Tolosa; one holding a sash and the other a shield; not the spurs and sword traditionally represented) and a boy holding a candle.Well-known scene and composition.Drawing is poor.
Don Quixote, Sancho Panza, the giant-windmill and the flock of sheep

In the foreground, don Quixote with Rocinante and Sancho Panza with his donkey.In the background, a windmill half-transformed into a giant and a flock of sheep.Vignette based on elements taken from Coypel's first illustration "Don Quixote's first sally"; framed by rocaille.Nice drawing and engraving.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the vignette appeared in the title pages of La Haye: Pierre de Hondt, 1746 and Amsterdam/Leipzig: Arkstée & Merkus, 1755.
EL INGENIOSO HIDALGO DON QUIXOTE DE LA MANCHA

Don Quixote with the allegory of Folly, as it was described by Cesare Ripa (dressed as a jester with small bells and holding a whirligig) and Love, as Cupid.Folly and Love show to don Quixote Dulcinea's portrait.Don Quixote appears as Knight of the Lions.A satyr (reference toDon Quixoteas a book of satire) sets fire to different chivalry books:Amadís de Grecia, El Caballero de la Cruz, Olivante de Laura...Good portrait of don Quixote.Drawing and engraving of great quality.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the frontispiece appeared in Madrid: Ibarra, 1780.
RETRATO DE CERVANTES DE SAAVEDRA POR EL MISMO.

Cervantes' portrait sat at a table, holding a quill and writing.In the background, a library with books behind a curtain.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable, although the image results forced (notice the right hand, the face...).

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amsterdam/Leipzig: Arkstée & Merkus, 1755.2 - Model of Cervantes' portrait designed by William Kent for London: Tonson, 1738; now, Cervantes' left hand is clearly-visible.3 - The window with don Quixote and Sancho in the background has not been copied and Cervantes' figure has been turned.4 - Jacob Folkema engraved this portrait in 1739 for an edition of theNovelas Ejemplares.
SANCHO PANÇA. DON QUIXOTE DE LA MANCHA. AMADIS. ROLANDO. DULCINEA

Don Quixote with the barber basin and Rocinante. Sancho with his donkey. Well-defined iconography.Over the left pedestal, "AMADIS"; over the right one, "ROLANDO". Both as classical statues.Above, a medallion with Dulcinea's portrait.Drawing is clumsy and disproportionate.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 (same plate first used for Brussels: Mommarte, 1662; copy by unknown engraver after Savery's frontispiece for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657).
Don Quixote fights with the muleteers and is knighted by the Innkeeper
3.3 Fight with muleteer3.4 DQ knighted at inn by innkeeper

Two different scenes (archaic):The first one, in the background: don Quixote fights with the muleteers during the vigil of his arms.The second one, in the foreground: don Quixote is knighted by the innkeeper while doña Molinera fits his spurs and doña Tolosa his sword.The boy holding a candle that appears in Cervantes' text is missing.Simple drawing; illustration with not many details and with very basic burin lines.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73.2 - "La venta donde el héroe es armado caballero, en pleno día -cuando Cervantes la describió en plena noche-, es una vasta y buena posada flamenca, con amplias dependencias y árboles frondosos. Las mozas del partido son sirvientas solícitas, de carnes blancas y abundantes. El ventero viste como un burgués de Gante, con sombrero emplumado y espada al cinto" (Givanel 108-109).

In the foreground, Juan Haldudo whips Andrés, while in the background don Quixote appears to his assistance.Drawing is ingenuous, disproportionate and without many details, but this composition will be used until the 20th century.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73.2 - Bouttats re-organized Savery's composition (Dordrecht: Savery, 1657).
Don Quixote is beaten by a silk merchants' groom and is rescued by Pedro Alonso
5.1 End of first sally5.2 DQ rescued by Pedro Alonso

Two different scenes in the same plate (archaic):The first one, in the background: don Quixote is beaten by the Toledo silk merchants' groom.The second scene, in the foreground: don Quixote is taken back home on Pedro Alonso's mule; Rocinante follows them with don Quixote's arms.Drawing and engraving are good.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73
Don Quixote fighting with the windmills and with the Basque
8.2 Adventure of the windmills (giants)8.3 Episode with friars of St. Benedict8.4 Adventure with the Basque

Three different scenes in the same plate (archaic):In the background, the first one: don Quixote attacks the windmills while Sancho tries to stop him.In the middle ground, the second one: Sancho is beaten by the Benedictine monks' servants.In the foreground, don Quixote fights with the Basque, while a Basque lady observes them from her carriage.The Basque holding a stool is not accurate to Cervantes' text; it should be a cushion.Clumsy drawing, figures without movement and wrong perspective (windmills).

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 (same plate first engraved for Brussels: Mommarte, 1662, which copied Savery's design for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657).
14.3 Marcela’s appearance and speech14.4 Burial of Grisóstomo

The background is divided in two parts: down, the dead shepherd, his friend Ambrosio, Vivaldo reading Grisóstomo's song and don Quixote; up, Marcela's appearance and speech.Marcela's figure copies saint Gabriel's traditional image.In the foreground, several shepherds digging Grisóstomo's grave.The burin work is simple.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 (same plate by unknown engraver first engraved for Brussels: Mommarte, 1662, which copied Savery's design for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657).
Night adventure at the inn with Maritornes

In the foreground, don Quixote lying over the broken bed.In the background, the fight between Sancho, Maritornes and the muleteer is discovered by the innkeeper, who holds a candle.The engraving is crude.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 (same plate by unknown engraver first engraved for Brussels: Mommarte, 1662, which was a bad copy after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657).
Sancho Panza's blanketing / Don Quixote fighting with the flock of sheep

Two different scenes in the same plate (archaic):In the foreground, at Juan Palomeque's inn, Sancho's blanketing is observed by don Quixote from behind the inn wall.In the background, don Quixote fighting with a flock of sheep.Simple composition that will be used until the 20th century.Drawing and engraving are poor and simple.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 (same plate by unknown engraver first engraved for Brussels: Mommarte, 1662, which was a clumsy copy after Savery's composition for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657).

In the foreground, don Quixote defeating Alonso López.In the background, the funeral procession companions escaping in great confusion.The engraving, not much detailed, is acceptable, creating a good impression of movement.The night representation is badly resolved; the torch light effects are simple.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73.
Cardenio attacks don Quixote and Sancho Panza
24.1 Story of Cardenio24.3 Cardenio attacks DQ and SP

In the foreground, after defeating don Quixote, Cardenio hits Sancho; the goatherd goes to their assistance.Simple composition.Drawing and engraving are bad and poor in details; figures without naturalism and artificial gestures.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 (same plate by unknown engraver first engraved for Brussels: Mommarte, 1662, which was a bad copy after Savery's composition for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657).
Don Quixote's penance in Sierra Morena

Sancho, with a broom bunch (accurate to Cervantes' text), leaves for El Toboso on Rocinante, while don Quixote remains doing penance (half-naked, doing a somersault in an undecorous manner).Drawing and engraving are acceptable.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73.
Don Quixote fighting with some muleteers during the vigil of his arms / Don Quixote knighted by the innkeeper
3.2 Vigil of arms3.3 Fight with muleteer3.4 DQ knighted at inn by innkeeper

Two different scenes (archaic):The first one, in the background: don Quixote fights with the muleteers during the vigil of his arms.The second one, in the foreground: don Quixote is knighted by the innkeeper while doña Molinera holds a candle (not the spurs) and doña Tolosa don Quixote's sword.Other men observe the scene.The boy holding the candle that appears in Cervantes' text has not been represented.Drawing and engraving are quite remarkable; detailed figures and fine burin lines.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Turned and improved copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Bouttats' illustration for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73; some figures and elements (candle) are new or have been changed.
In the foreground, Juan Haldudo (richly dressed) whipping Andrés; meanwhile, from the background, don Quixote appears to his assistance.Drawing and engraving are quite good.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 - Copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Bouttats' illustration for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73; some figures have been turned and Juan Haldudo's horse included (as it appeared in Bouttats' illus.).
Don Quixote beaten by a silk merchants' groom / Don Quixote taken back home by Pedro Alonso
5.1 End of first sally5.2 DQ rescued by Pedro Alonso

Two different scenes in the same plate (archaic):The first one, in the background: don Quixote is beaten by the Toledo silk merchants' groom.The second scene, in the foreground: don Quixote is taken back home on Pedro Alonso's mule; Rocinante carries don Quixote's arms.Drawing and engraving are quite good; well-drawn figures and fine burin lines.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Turned copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Bouttats' illustration for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73.
Don Quixote fighting against a windmill / Don Quixote fighting with the Basque
8.2 Adventure of the windmills (giants)8.3 Episode with friars of St. Benedict8.4 Adventure with the Basque

Two different scenes in the same plate (archaic):In the background, the first one: don Quixote attacking the windmills while Sancho, knelt, prays.On the right, two Benedictine monks on their mules (?).In the foreground, the second one: don Quixote fights with the Basque, while a Basque lady observes them from her carriage.The Basque holding a shield (?) is not accurate to Cervantes' text; it should be a cushion.Drawing and engraving are very acceptable despite some disproportions in background figures.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657 (also in Brussels: Mommarte, 1662 and Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73); Sancho´s figure is new.
14.1 Episode of Grisóstomo and Marcela, continuation14.2 Grisóstomo´s song14.3 Marcela’s appearance and speech14.4 Burial of Grisóstomo

The background is divided in two parts: down, Grisóstomo's corpse, his friend Ambrosio, Vivaldo reading Grisóstomo's song, don Quixote on Rocinante and other shepherds holding tapers; up, Marcela's appearance and speech.In the foreground, a pair of shepherds digging Grisóstomo's grave.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657 (also in Brussels: Mommarte, 1662 and Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73).

In the foreground, don Quixote lying on the broken bed.In the background, the fight between Sancho, Maritornes and the muleteer is discovered by the innkeeper, who holds a candle.Drawing and engraving are good despite some fault (muleteer).

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Turned copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657 (also in Brussels: Mommarte, 1662 and Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73).
Sancho's blanketing / Don Quixote fighting with a flock of sheep

Two different scenes in the same plate (archaic):In the foreground, at Juan Palomeque's inn, Sancho's blanketing is observed by don Quixote from behind the inn wall.In the background, don Quixote fighting with a flock of sheep.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable despite some disproportions among figures.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657 (also in Brussels: Mommarte, 1662 and Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73).

In the foreground, don Quixote after defeating Alonso López, fallen with his mule; Sancho observes the scene.In the background, the funeral procession companions holding tapers and torches; some of them flee away.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable.Alonso López's figure, falling from his mule, is remarkable.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Bouttats' illustration for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73; don Quixote's figure has been moved backwards, so now he is attacking another ecclesiastic, not Alonso López.
Don Quixote releases the galley slaves

Two different scenes in the same illustration (archaic):In the foreground, don Quixote defeating one of the slaves guards while another one on horseback flees away.In the background, the consequence: don Quixote and Sancho Panza are stoned by the same slaves.Drawing and engraving are good.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Bouttats' illustration for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73.
Cardenio attacks don Quixote and Sancho
24.1 Story of Cardenio24.3 Cardenio attacks DQ and SP
In the foreground, after defeating don Quixote, Cardenio beats Sancho with his fist; the goatherd goes to their assistance.Simple composition.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657 (also in Brussels: Mommarte, 1662 and Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73).
Don Quixote´s penance in Sierra Morena
25.4 SP’s embassy to Dulcinea;25.5 DQ performs mad acts

Sancho, with a broom bunch (accurate to Cervantes' text), leaves for El Toboso mounted on Rocinante, while don Quixote remains doing penance in Sierra Morena (half-naked, doing a somersault in an undecorous manner).Don Quixote's arms remain hung on a tree.Drawing and engraving quite good.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Bouttats' illustration for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73.
D. Quixote, condusido, por la Locura, y ardiendo en el amor extravagante de Dulcinea, sale de su Caza para ser Cavallero errante.

Don Quixote's first sally allegorical representation.Don Quixote, mounted on Rocinante, protected by Folly (with the barber basin and a jester scepter) and Love (Cupid holding a torch touching don Quixote's heart and pointing to Dulcinea).Dulcinea appears as a French Lady carrying wheat, as Sancho refers in chapter 31:1.In the background, a windmill half-transformed into a giant (8:1) and a flock of sheep with lances (18:1).Drawing and engraving are excellent.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amsterdam/Leipzig: Arkstée & Merkus, 1755.2 - Copy after Coypel's design (first appeared in Surugue: Paris, c. 1724; also copied for La Haye: Pierre de Hondt, 1746).2 - Same plate first engraved for La Haye: P. Gosse & A. Moetjens, 1744.
D. Quixote cree de recebir en la Venta el Orden de Cavalleria.
3.4 DQ knighted at inn by innkeeper

Accurate to Cervantes' text, the innkeeper, holding a sword and a book, knights don Quixote, knelt before him.Doña Tolosa holds don Quixote's sword and doña Molinera a shield (it should be don Quixote's spurs).It also appears the boy with a candle.Two other women (the one next to a well is very remarkable), do not belong to Cervantes' text.Drawing and engraving are excellent.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amsterdam/Leipzig: Arkstée & Merkus, 1755.2 - Copy after Coypel's design (first appeared in Surugue: Paris, 1724; also copied for La Haye: Pierre de Hondt, 1746).3 - Same plate first engraved for La Haye: P. Gosse & A. Moetjens, 1744.
D. Quixote toma la Bazia de un Barbero, por el Yelmo de Mambrino.
21.3 Adventure of the helmet of Mambrino

In the foreground, don Quixote, with great dignity, puts the barber basin on his head, while Sancho Panza laughs.In the background, the barber running away and leaving his mule fallen.Two women (not accurate to Cervantes' text) observe the scene.Well-detailed drawing and engraving.See rainbow in the background; it has rained at the beginning of this episode.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amsterdam/Leipzig: Arkstée & Merkus, 1755.2 - Copy after Coypel's design (first appeared in Surugue: Paris, c. 1728-30; also copied for La Haye: Pierre de Hondt, 1746).3 - Same plate first engraved for La Haye: P. Gosse & A. Moetjens, 1744.
Don Quixote knighted by the innkeeper
3.4 DQ knighted at inn by innkeeper

Don Quixote, knelt in the inn courtyard, is knighted by the innkeeper, who holds a book and raises a sword.Also in the scene, the two party girls (doña Molinera and doña Tolosa; one holding a sash and the other a shield; not the spurs and sword traditionally represented) and a boy holding a candle.Well-known scene and composition.Drawing is poor.
Don Quixote, Sancho Panza, the giant-windmill and the flock of sheep

In the foreground, don Quixote with Rocinante and Sancho Panza with his donkey.In the background, a windmill half-transformed into a giant and a flock of sheep.Vignette based on elements taken from Coypel's first illustration "Don Quixote's first sally"; framed by rocaille.Nice drawing and engraving.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the vignette appeared in the title pages of La Haye: Pierre de Hondt, 1746 and Amsterdam/Leipzig: Arkstée & Merkus, 1755.
EL INGENIOSO HIDALGO DON QUIXOTE DE LA MANCHA

Don Quixote with the allegory of Folly, as it was described by Cesare Ripa (dressed as a jester with small bells and holding a whirligig) and Love, as Cupid.Folly and Love show to don Quixote Dulcinea's portrait.Don Quixote appears as Knight of the Lions.A satyr (reference toDon Quixoteas a book of satire) sets fire to different chivalry books:Amadís de Grecia, El Caballero de la Cruz, Olivante de Laura...Good portrait of don Quixote.Drawing and engraving of great quality.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the frontispiece appeared in Madrid: Ibarra, 1780.
Don Quixote and Sancho find a suitcase with clothes

In Sierra Morena, don Quixote and Sancho find a portmanteau with some rich clothes, money and one book (Cardenio's).Sancho observes the clothes while don Quixote reads the book.Good illustration as a whole, but some details are clumsy (compare don Quixote's hand and head).Highly-detailed burin engraving; good shading (clothes, vegetation...).
1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Madrid: Ibarra, 1780.
SANCHO PANÇA. DON QUIXOTE DE LA MANCHA. AMADIS. ROLANDO. DULCINEA

Don Quixote with the barber basin and Rocinante. Sancho with his donkey. Well-defined iconography.Over the left pedestal, "AMADIS"; over the right one, "ROLANDO". Both as classical statues.Above, a medallion with Dulcinea's portrait.Drawing is clumsy and disproportionate.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 (same plate first used for Brussels: Mommarte, 1662; copy by unknown engraver after Savery's frontispiece for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657).
Don Quixote releases the galley slaves

Two different scenes in the same illustration (archaic):In the foreground, don Quixote defeats one of the slaves guards while Sancho releases the galley slaves.In the background, the consequence: don Quixote and Sancho Panza are stoned by the same slaves.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73.2 - This illustration (22:1) should appear before "DQ and SP beaten by Cardenio" (24:1).
Dispute at the inn about Mambrino's helmet (barber basin) and packsaddle
45.1 Dispute at inn about the Mambrino’s helmet and packsaddle (albarda)

In the center of the composition, don Quixote with Mambrino's helmet (basin) shouting to calm down the fight around him (Agramante's Camp); also don Fernando, officers of the Holy Brotherhood, innkeeper...On the left, Sancho and the barber fighting for the packsaddle.Drawing and engraving are acceptable.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 (same plate by unknown engraver first engraved for Brussels: Mommarte, 1662, which was a bad copy after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657).2 - Placed in chapter 30:1 according to its own reference (Fol. 331), but this illustration should appear in chapter 45:1, where "DQ punishing SP" has been placed.
Resolution of love affairs of Cardenio and Dorotea, Luscinda and don Fernando
36.2 Resolution of love affairs of Cardenio and Luscinda, Dorotea and Don Fernando

Dorotea recognises don Fernando and Luscinda, who has lost her mask (tafetán), and, knelt before don Fernando, begs him to let Luscinda go with Cardenio; Sancho, the priest and the barber observe them."Había en este entretanto vuelto Dorotea en sí, y había estado escuchando todas las razones que Luscinda dijo, por las cuales vino en conocimiento de quien ella era: que viendo que Don Fernando aun no la dejaba de sus brazos, ni respondía á sus razones, fué á hincar de rodillas á sus pies" (36:1).Drawing and engraving are acceptable.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 (same plate by unknown engraver first engraved for Brussels: Mommarte, 1662, which was a bad copy after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657).
Maritornes and the innkeeper's daughter hang don Quixote from a window by a hand; four travelers arrive to the inn
43.2 Maritornes and innkeeper’s daughter hang DQ from window by a hand43.3 Four travelers arrive at inn

Don Quixote falls from Rocinante and remains hung and tied by his hand to a window when four travelers (servants of don Luis' father) arrive to the inn. Rocinante has moved to smell one of the mares.The innkeeper appears to discover who is shouting.Maritornes is ready to untie don Quixote, but the innkeeper's daughter should not appear in the window too.Drawing and engraving are acceptable.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73.

Dorotea (Micomicona) prevents don Quixote from punishing Sancho for having preferred Micomicona's beauty to Dulcinea's. Also the priest, Cardenio and the barber, disguised.Drawing and engraving are acceptable.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 (same plate by unknown engraver first used for Brussels: Mommarte, 1662, which was a bad copy after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657).2 - Placed in chapter 45:1 according to its own reference (Fol. 537), but this illustration should appear in chapter 30:1, where "Dispute at the inn" has been placed.
Don Quixote fights with the goatherd and encounters the penitents
52.1 Fight with the goatherd52.2 Encounter with penitents (disciplinantes)

Two different scenes in the same plate:The first one, in the background: don Quixote fights with the goatherd while the priest, the barber, the officers of the Holy Brotherhood and the canon of Toledo observe them; one of the canon's servants grabs Sancho to prevent him from helping his master.The second scene, in the foreground: Sancho takes care of don Quixote, defeated by one of the penitents, while the priest talks to another priest."El Cura fué conocido de otro Cura, que en la procesión venía, cuyo conocimiento puso en sosiego el concebido temor de los escuadrones" (52:1).Drawing is disproportionate in some parts.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73.

Don Quixote hits Sancho with his lance because the squire prefers Micomicona's beauty to Dulcinea's; Sancho has fallen on the ground; Micomicona (Dorotea), the priest, Cardenio and the barber try to prevent don Quixote from punishing Sancho again.It shouldn't be set with an architecture (inn?) in the background.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable; poor setting.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving for Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700.
36.2 Resolution of love affairs of Cardenio and Luscinda, Dorotea and Don Fernando

Dorotea recognises don Fernando and Luscinda, who has lost her mask (tafetán), and, knelt before don Fernando, begs him to let Luscinda go with Cardenio; Sancho, the priest and the barber observe them."Había en este entretanto vuelto Dorotea en sí, y había estado escuchando todas las razones que Luscinda dijo, por las cuales vino en conocimiento de quien ella era: que viendo que Don Fernando aun no la dejaba de sus brazos, ni respondía á sus razones, fué á hincar de rodillas á sus pies" (36:1).Drawing and engraving are quite good.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657 (also in Brussels: Mommarte, 1662 and Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73).
Don Quixote hanged by his hand tied to a window
43.2 Maritornes and innkeeper’s daughter hang DQ from window by a hand43.3 Four travelers arrive at inn

Four travelers on horseback arrive to the inn (servants of don Luis' father) and encounter don Quixote standing on Rocinante with his hand tied to a window of the inn.Original image.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving for Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700.
Dispute at the inn about Mambrino's helmet (barber basin) and packsaddle
45.1 Dispute at inn about the Mambrino’s helmet and packsaddle (albarda)

At the inn courtyard, don Quixote wearing Mambrino's helmet (basin), don Fernando, officers of justice, innkeeper, Sancho, the barber (these two on the left)... all fighting.On the right, standing up, the priest, the innkeeper's wife and Maritornes.Drawing and engraving are very good.Very original image.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Clouzier's engraving for Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700 (after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657) has not been copied.
Don Quixote defeated by a penitent

Sancho takes care of don Quixote, defeated by one of the penitents, while the priest talk to another priest. "El Cura fué conocido de otro Cura, que en la procesión venía, cuyo conocimiento puso en sosiego el concebido temor de los escuadrones" (52:1).Drawing and engraving are good; don Quixote and Sancho's figures are very remarkable.

Entrada del Amor y del Interés, a las Bodas de Camacho.

Well-ballanced composition.In the center is Cupid, dancing in front of a castle where a Virgin is protected.On the left, as part of Cupid's retinue, Poetry (with Fame's trumpet), Discretion (as a prudent virgin with a small oil lamp), Nobility (as Athena) and Valour (with a crown).On the left, Wealth and his retinue: Liberality (with the cornucopia and a pair of compasses) and Largesse.They should also appear Treasure and Quiet Possession, but they are missing. The first retinue refers to Basilio, the second one to Camacho.Sancho only eats while don Quixote observes this performance.Rich and great scene where it is reflected 18th century liking for court theater and allegorical and symbolic literature.Drawing and engraving of excellent quality.

Don Antonio Moreno shows the enchanted head to don Quixote and Sancho

Two different scenes in the same illustration:In the foreground, don Antonio Moreno shows the enchanted head to don Quixote, Sancho, his wife and some friends. Accurate to Cervantes' text, the head has the shape of a Roman bust.In the background, a previous scene: don Quixote in Barcelona with a parchment on his back and his name written in it.Rich and bourgeois setting.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73.
The Knight of the White Moon defeats don Quixote
64.1 DQ is defeated by the Knight of the White Moon (Sansón Carrasco)

In the foreground, don Quixote defeated by the Knight of the White Moon (Sansón Carrasco).In the background, Sancho, don Antonio Moreno, the viceroy and others in the beach of Barcelona (galley and tower).This composition became canonical.The engraving is poor (see background details).

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73 (same plate by unknown engraver first used for Brussels: Mommarte, 1662, which was a copy after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657).
The death of Altisidora and Sancho pinched by dueñas
69.1 DQ and SP back the Dukes´ palace69.2 Altisidora’s mock death and resurrection

In the foreground, the humorous action: don Quixote orders Sancho to let the Dueñas pinch him; "Ten paciencia, hijo, y da gusto a estos Señores, y muchas gracias al cielo, por haber puesto tal virtud en tu persona" (69:2).Sancho is wearing a tunic with flames and a mitre (it should be a conic hood orcapiroteas used inAutos de Fe).In the background, more theatrical and dramatic, Altisidora appears lying on a catafalque; also a boy ("un hermoso mancebo vestido á lo Romano") playing the harp, the Duque, the Duchess, Minos and Radamanto (as kings).The engraving is better executed in the foreground figures than in background ones.
1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73.
35.1 Merlin’s prophecy about Dulcinea and remedy for her enchantment

In the foreground, with their backs turned on the viewer, the Duke, the Duchess, don Quixote and Sancho; they observe the entry of Merlin´s cart with Dulcinea (in the background).Merlin should appear as Death, not as a magician.Drawing and engraving are acceptable; detailed figures and setting; some disproportions.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 - Turned copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657 (also in Brussels: Mommarte, 1662 and Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73); don Quixote and Sancho's figure have been changed.
Don Quixote and Sancho mounted on Rocinante
41.1 Adventure of Clavileño41.2 DQ and SP fly on Clavileño

In the foreground, don Quixote and Sancho mounted on Clavileño; two servants simulate its flight with a pair of bellows and one torch.In the background, before their palace, the Duke and the Duchess observe the scene.Drawing and engraving are quite good; notice the figures in the foreground.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657 (also in Brussels: Mommarte, 1662 and Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73); the servant lighting Clavileño's fuse has not been copied and some figures (Duke, Duchess, palace) moved.

Governor Sancho, represented with dignity, judges the case of a man accused of rape.In the foreground, the accused man tries to recover the money that, by order of Sancho, he has given to the accusing woman.Good setting.Engraving of unequal quality; worn plate.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Bouttats' illustration for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73; some gestures have been changed.
48.1 Doña Rodríguez visits DQ at night in his room

In the foreground, two maidens beat doña Rodríguez's ass with a slipper; "que la asían de la garganta con dos manos tan fuertemente, que no la dejaban gañir, y que otra persona con mucha presteza, sin hablar palabra, le alzaba las faldas, y con un al parecer chinela, le comenzó á dar tantos azotes que era una compasión" (48:2).In the background, don Quixote in his bed observing the scene.Accurate details (see the fallen candle; it should be extinguished).Drawing and engraving are quite good; very worn plate.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Modified copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Bouttats' illustration for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73; the scene in the background (don Quixote beaten by other maidens) has not been copied, so now the illus. is more accurate to Cervantes' text.
Sancho during the invasion of Barataria Island

At Barataria Island, governor Sancho, tied between two shields and fallen on the floor, is trampled by some soldiers fighting with swords and torches.Acceptable setting.Drawing and engraving are good.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 - Previous illus. by Savery (Dordrecht: Savery, 1657) or Clouzier (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) have been modified; never before Sancho had appeared fallen on the floor.

Don Quixote defeated by the Knight of the White Moon
64.1 DQ is defeated by the Knight of the White Moon (Sansón Carrasco)

In the foreground, don Quixote defeated by the Knight of the White Moon (Sansón Carrasco).In the background, Sancho, don Antonio Moreno, the viceroy and others in Barcelona beach (galley and city).Drawing and engraving are quite good despite some faults.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Modified and improved copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Savery's illustration for Dordrecht: Savery, 1657 (also in Brussels: Mommarte, 1662 and Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73).
Altisidora's death and Sancho pinched by dueñas
69.1 DQ and SP back the Dukes´ palace69.2 Altisidora’s mock death and resurrection

In the foreground, the humorous action: don Quixote orders Sancho to let the Dueñas pinch him; "Ten paciencia, hijo, y da gusto a estos Señores, y muchas gracias al cielo, por haber puesto tal virtud en tu persona" (69:2).Sancho is wearing a tunic and a mitre (it should be a conic hood orcapiroteas used inAutos de Fe).In the background, more theatrical and dramatic, Altisidora appears lying on a catafalque; also a boy ("un hermoso mancebo vestido á lo Romano") playing the harp, the Duque, the Duchess, Minos and Radamanto (as kings).Drawing and engraving are good.

1 - Photomechanical copy of the illustration appeared in Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1713.2 – Copy after Clouzier's engraving (Paris: Compagnie des Libraires, 1700) after Bouttats' illustration for Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73; new setting.
Pusilanimidad de Sancho en la Caça.

In the center of the composition, don Quixote driving his sword into an enormous wild boar surrounded by hunting dogs; Coypel emphasizes drama in this scene.In the background, the Duke embracing the Duchess; she looks like a new Diana.In the foreground, but just in one side, the humorous part: Sancho flees away climbing a tree.Excellent drawing and engraving; detailed setting and good expressions.

1 - Photomechanical copy (quite rough) of the illustration appeared in Amsterdam/Leipzig: Arkstée & Merkus, 1755.2 - Copy after Coypel's design (first appeared in Surugue: Paris, c. 1728-30; also copied for La Haye: Pierre de Hondt, 1746).3 - Same plate first engraved for La Haye: P. Gosse & A. Moetjens, 1744.
La Dolorida, afligida de su barba, viene a rogar a D. Quixote de vengarla.

Countess Trifaldi shows her beard to don Quixote, amazing him and Sancho.The composition is created with gestures and looks: the Duchess orders two maidens to be quiet; the Duke laughs; Sancho's surprised; don Quixote's astonished.Trifaldín's figure is very remarkable, although he should hold a scimitar, not a mace.Well-detailed drawing engraving; good expressions.

1 - Photomechanical copy (deficient) of the illustration appeared in Amsterdam/Leipzig: Arkstée & Merkus, 1755.2 - Copy after Coypel's design (first appeared in Surugue: Paris, 1724; also copied for La Haye: Pierre de Hondt, 1746).3 - Same plate first engraved for La Haye: P. Gosse & A. Moetjens, 1744.
